<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 730, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 41, 507, 58]]<|/det|>
## 2  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 128, 91]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 640, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 565, 170, 582]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 598, 324, 615]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 650, 252, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 682, 154, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 723, 341, 741]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 762, 208, 779]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 794, 230, 810]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 828, 240, 845]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 98, 640, 520]]<|/det|>
\[g = 9.81 \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\] \[c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\] \[e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\] \[1 \mathrm{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\] \[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}\] \[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\] \[R = 8.31 \mathrm{J K}^{-1} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\] \[k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{J K}^{-1}\] \[G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{N m}^{2} \mathrm{kg}^{-2}\] \[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{F m}^{-1}\] \[\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{m F}^{-1})\] \[h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{J s}\] \[\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{W m}^{-2} \mathrm{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 598, 583, 636]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 650, 551, 668]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 680, 544, 698]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 712, 555, 747]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{V\pm V_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 760, 554, 780]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 792, 608, 811]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 821, 615, 855]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 670, 92]]<|/det|>
The drag force \(F_{\mathrm{D}}\) acting on an object falling through air is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 96, 559, 125]]<|/det|>
\[F_{\mathrm{D}} = \frac{1}{2} C\rho A\nu^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 524, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the object,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 149, 494, 167]]<|/det|>
\(\nu\) is the velocity of the object in the air,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 164, 425, 182]]<|/det|>
\(\rho\) is the density of the air and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 180, 520, 198]]<|/det|>
C is a constant called the drag coefficient.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 146, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 685, 229]]<|/det|>
Use SI base units to show that the drag coefficient has no units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 146, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 618, 431]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows a sphere falling at terminal velocity in air.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 442, 757, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 552, 532, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 591, 603]]<|/det|>
Assume that the upthrust on the sphere is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 918, 649]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, draw and label arrows to show the directions of the **two** forces acting on the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 146, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 416, 680]]<|/det|>
The mass of the sphere is \(49\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 561, 711]]<|/det|>
Calculate the drag force \(F_{\mathrm{D}}\) acting on the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 831, 920, 851]]<|/det|>
<form>F_D = ............................................................ N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 730, 89]]<|/det|>
The sphere is falling in air at a terminal velocity of 25 in SI base units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 520, 104]]<|/det|>
The density of the air is 1.2 in SI base units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 591, 120]]<|/det|>
The diameter of the sphere is 0.060 in SI base units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 747, 151]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(c)** to calculate the drag coefficient \(C\) for the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 339, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
<form>C = ............................................................ [3]

<mark>[Total: 10]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 776, 183]]<|/det|>
A student throws a ball over a vertical wall of height \(h\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 195, 876, 405]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 424, 591, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 880, 472]]<|/det|>
The ball leaves the hand of the student at a height of \(1.2 \text{m}\) above the horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 469, 784, 488]]<|/det|>
The ball has an initial velocity of \(22 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(40^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 826, 503]]<|/det|>
The wall is a horizontal distance of \(36 \text{m}\) from where the student releases the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 378, 535]]<|/det|>
Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 181, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 548, 641, 567]]<|/det|>
Determine the time taken for the ball to reach the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 718, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
<form>time taken = ...................................................... $s$

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
An object of mass \(2m\) is travelling at a speed of \(5.0 \text{ m s}^{-1}\) in a straight line. It collides with an object of mass \(3m\) which is initially stationary, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 240, 734, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
After the collision, the object of mass \(2m\) moves with velocity \(v\) at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to its original direction of motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 900, 431]]<|/det|>
The object of mass \(3m\) moves with velocity \(w\) also at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\), as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 439, 870, 664]]<|/det|>

<form>v = .................................................... $m s^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<form>w = .................................................... $m s^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 920, 447]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A stretched string PQ has length \(1.2 \text{m}\). One end of the string is attached to a vibration generator and the other end is attached to a wall, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 366, 89]]<|/det|>
State Kirchhoff's first law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A cell with internal resistance \(r\) is connected to two resistors of resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 203, 720, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 407, 532, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 794, 458]]<|/det|>
The potential differences (p.d.s) across \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) are \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 460, 473]]<|/det|>
The terminal p.d. across the cell is \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 395, 488]]<|/det|>
The current in the circuit is \(I.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 888, 519]]<|/det|>
Use Kirchhoff's laws to show that the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the external circuit is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 530, 559, 551]]<|/det|>
\[R_{\mathrm{T}} = R_{1} + R_{2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 764, 920, 782]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 667, 89]]<|/det|>
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the cell in Fig. 6.1 is \(1.50 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The values of \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) are \(10 \Omega\) and \(15 \Omega\) respectively. The terminal p.d. of the cell is \(1.35 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 524, 148]]<|/det|>
Calculate the internal resistance \(r\) of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 285, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
<form>r = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 148, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 316, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
A resistor of resistance \(R_{3}\) is added to the circuit in Fig. 6.1, so that the circuit is as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 355, 710, 606]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 618, 534, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 648, 594, 666]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, of this change on:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 677, 183, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 677, 371, 695]]<|/det|>
the current in the cell

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 770, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 800, 181, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 800, 420, 819]]<|/det|>
the terminal p.d. of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 922, 920, 940]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Nuclei of an isotope of copper (Cu) each have 29 protons and 37 neutrons. This isotope is a \(\beta^{- }\) emitter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 710, 136]]<|/det|>
State the nuclide notation in the form \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X}\) for this nucleus of copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 146, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
The energy spectrum of the \(\beta^{- }\) radiation emitted by a sample of this isotope is shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 527, 532, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 181, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 556, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 7.1 to explain why other particles apart from the \(\beta^{- }\) particles must be emitted during this decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 727, 920, 745]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 758, 181, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 757, 821, 777]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>

The copper isotope decays to an isotope of zinc (Zn).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
